%text If the set of \underline\text{all possible events} $(S)$ be divided into smaller sets $E_1, E_2, \ldots$ such that % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{Nc}
\hline \text{Condition} & Meaning \\ \hline E_i\cap E_j = \phi\,(i\neq j) & \text{$E_i$ and $E_j$ are mutually} \\ &\text{exclusive $\forall \left( i, j\right) $} \\ \hline E_i\cup E_j\cup\ldots E_n = S & \text{$E_i\ldots E_n$ are exhaustive} \\ \hline E_i \neq \phi \,\forall\, $i$ & \text{No $E_i$ is empty} \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} %text then an event $A$ will intersect with \underline\text{some or all} of $E_1, E_2,\ldots E_n$ And hence, the \underline\text{probability of $A$} occurring will be the following \[ \qquad P(A) = \sum_{i=1}^n P\left( A\,\vert\, E_i\right)\cdot P(E_i)\] %
